{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3597503,"name":"6894 Lead prog/driver","username":"Mochatitan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mochatitan/{size}/237112_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-20T05:27:04.154Z","cooked":"

I am currently making software that logs data for the robot in the long term, so basically each time you shoot a number goes up which gets saved to a .txt file, and then at the end of the season you can see “heyy our robot placed 1700 coral” or something along those lines.

Now, It is coded, but for testing purposes, what is the easiest wayy to go about this? it isnt very easy to test in sim since it just uses my files to simulate, which is janky with how DS is supposed to work with it.
if i have a rio 2, can i just plug it into my laptop in some way, or do i need to bring the entire test board setup PDP battery and rio?

If you want to use a RIO as a benchtop test board, you’ll need some form of 12V power supply but other than that, you don’t really need much else. If you have a benchtop adjustable power supply, you can power it that way. That said, plenty of teams just zip-tie a RIO, PDH/PDP, and a standard FRC battery to a piece of wood for non-robot testing.

Mochatitan:

battery

We use something like THESE POWER SUPPLIES and there is enough capacity to run a motor at slow speed. I’m not sure what the minimum power is for the roboRIO 2 but you might get away with a very inexpensive 12VDC 2A wall wart if you have one.

You use the USB port to connect to your laptop without a radio but it doesn’t supply the power.

If you can be more specific about what you mean by

Mochatitan:

sim since it just uses my files to simulate, which is janky with how DS is supposed to work with it.

we might be able to help you with the files. You can use the WPILib data logs in PC sim mode exactly the same as on the roboRIO. Text files also work exactly the same at least in Java programs.
